Honestly, the worst thing about fgo is the story.
God it's so terrible sometimes. And what ruins the story is the fan service.
He's absolutely bland. He's absolutely everywhere. He has no skills. No real relevance to the story other than as a passive observer and a battery for the servants to use. 
And yet he is beloved and admired by everyone. Even by people who by all rights should see him as nothing more than a worm. Everyone has to be utterly positive about him all the time. Everyone is super subservient. Everyone wets themselves to spend time with him and get in his pants. Even the female servants with canonical love interests are all over him. And for absolutely no reason, it utterly breaks suspension of disbelief.
When Gilgamesh is treating this irrelevant battery like he's gods gift to humanity you know it's contrived.

And this disrupts everything else to do with the characters. No character interactioncan take place without the MC poking his head in and shit

(Part 21) That concludes the technical part of this hypothetical emulation. That’s one point, technically two, for Quetzalcoatl and zero for (Caster) Gilgamesh. In this next part we will be discussing the battle between these two, doing away with technical terms, and instead focusing on facts and events from the story to detail how the battle would play out. Tuck yourself in, we’re gonna have to do some digging. The rest comes next week.

(Part 20) The results are in, (Caster) Gilgamesh loses in both perspectives of the hypothetical battle emulation. Now you might think, “(Caster) Gilgamesh could have easily won if he had sub-skills from a Mystic Code or at the very least a decent Craft Essence equipped!” And while that’s undoubtedly true, this applies for both sides. Does it mean it’s a draw? Of course not. In the first place, the only servant who would have a master in this situation would be Quetzalcoatl. We are battling (Caster) Gilgamesh. I only included his perspective of the battle for fairness’ sake and thus took it upon myself to remove that privilege from Quetzalcoatl as well.

(Part 19) Yet again (Caster) Gilgamesh was defeated, except this time he didn’t even get to his turn. You could argue that maybe somewhere in the calculations my rounding caused something to drastically change the outcome, but I assure you, it had little to no impact.

(Part 18) Turn 1: Quetzalcoatl. She uses Charisma A+ and increases her ATK by 21% for 3 turns, and then uses Wisdom of a Benevolent God A+ which applies Guts for 1 turn and Increases her Buster Card Effectiveness by 20% for 3 turns. She uses her BABE Command Card Chain and proceeds to attack. She deals a fatal total of 76,308 damage. Enough to kill him 6 times over, (Caster) Gilgamesh has fallen.

(Part 17) You might claim I maliciously left out the use of his first skill, King’s Return A, to leave him at a disadvantage, when the reality is he wouldn’t’ve lasted the turn regardless to utilize the Critical Stars to attack with next turn due to the fact that he would fail to survive, and was thus defeated by Quetzalcoatl on the same turn. And as you may have noticed I purposefully left out the use Quetzalcoatl’s last skill, Lucha Libre EX, since she as well wouldn’t’ve of needed it as we can see in the one turn it took her to fell (Caster) Gilgamesh. Moving on to Quetzalcoatl’s side of the Emulation.

(Part 16) (Caster) Gilgamesh has been defeated. Unfortunately the online Command Card Chain Calculator doesn’t detail individual Command Card damage and frankly I’m not ready to do the surprisingly massive damage formula required to find out. I’ve used her before and she can easily deal over 12k Effective Damage in unison with her skills and a single Buster Command Card, you’re just gonna have to trust me on this conjecture.

(Part 15) Turn 1: Quetzalcoatl. She uses Charisma A+ and increases her ATK by 21% for 3 turns, and then uses Wisdom of a Benevolent God A+ which applies Guts for 1 turn and Increases her Buster Card Effectiveness by 20% for 3 turns. Having used 2 actions thus far, for her final action she uses a Buster Command Card and proceeds to attack. She deals a fatal total of around 19k damage. (Caster) Gilgamesh has fallen.

(Part 14) Turn 1: (Caster) Gilgamesh. He uses Charisma A+ and increases his ATK by 21% for 3 turns, he then uses Sovereign of the Magical Staff EX and raises his Arts Card Effectiveness by 30% for 3 turns. He uses his BAAE Command Card Chain and proceeds to attack. He deals a total of 11,855 damage to Quetzalcoatl. It’s not enough to kill her, she retains 1,145 HP.

(Part 13) F:GO is a turn based game, although, instead of one side having a turn to themselves, both sides can act on the same turn and so forth, but the first turn advantage is still valid even in this system. The player’s side can use as many skills on the first turn as they want and attack using 3 Command Cards. While the opposing side is limited to 3 actions, which is usually an NPC, but since I’m writing this and I don’t possess the generated randomness of an AI all the actions will be predetermined, the use of a skill and an attack is considered an action. So to remain unbiased, fair, and faithful to F:GO’s core game mechanics, we will be emulating this from both perspectives.

(Part 12) Now for the actual performance in-battle we shall shortly be ‘witnessing’ I shall use Gamepress.gg and utilize their online “Command Chain Damage Calculator,” which will factor in the listed stats, skills, Command Cards- as well as a couple passive buffs I took the freedom upon myself to omit as they have almost next to no impact in this battle emulation, and do all the necessary math to properly calculate the damage each servant will be dealing.
(Part 11) For Quetzalcoatl, her most damaging Command Chain is Buster, Arts, Buster, and an Extra Attack, BABE for short.

(Part 10) For all intents and purposes, when it comes to their Command Cards, we shall be only be utilizing their most damaging Command Card chain. As a small digression, there are 3 main Command Card types: Buster, excels in raw damage. Arts, excels in Noble Phantasm Gain Rate. Lastly, Quick, which excels in Critical Star Generation. In (Caster) Gilgamesh’s case it’s Buster, Arts, Arts, and an Extra Attack (a bonus Command Card awarded at the end of a “Brave Chain,” which activates when 3 Command Cards of the same servant are chosen) BAAE, for short.

(Part 9) Quetzalcoatl’s skills are as follow: Charisma A+, this skill is the same as (Caster) Gilgamesh’s Charisma A+ skill, it raises all fielded servants ATK by 21% for 3 turns, in this case only her own. Her next skill, Wisdom of the Benevolent God A+, this skill applies Guts for 1 turn (a status which lets a servant revive after their HP drops to 0) which restores 1000 HP when activated, as well as increase her Buster Card Effectiveness by 20% for 3 turns. Her final skill, Lucha Libre EX, raises her Critical Star Gather Rate by 600% for 1 turn, increases her Critical Strength (critical hit damage) by 50% for 1 turn, and increases her Noble Phantasm Gauge by 30%. This skill is also useless in this emulation and you’ll see why next.

(Part 8) (Caster) Gilgamesh’s skills are as follow: King’s Return A, this skill raises his Critical Star Generation/Drop Rate by 100% for 3 turns, while pretty stellar this particular skill is useless for this emulation and you’ll see why soon. His next skill, Charisma A+, this raises all fielded servants ATK by 21% for 3 turns, in this case only his own. His final skill, Sovereign of Magical Staff EX, raises all fielded servants Arts Card Effectiveness (Command Card Effectiveness buffs influence the following: Critical Star Generation, Noble Phantasm Gain Rate, and most importantly in this case, Command Card damage) by 30% for 3 turns, again in this case, only his own. Now we move onto Quetzalcoatl’s skills.

(Part 7) Now we arrive at their skill sets. All servants have three skills. Their skills vastly influence the performance of themselves and their team mates. As another side note, no, neither of them will have team mates for this emulation. I may or may not include that element later in the story emulation of the hypothetical battle.

(Part 6) As a side note, we won’t be including Craft Essences (CEs, they increase base stats and certain attributes) or Mystic Codes (MCs, a pseudo skill set utilized by masters) in this hypothetical fight, due to the fact that it would be quite the disservice to this unbiased, factually based, though somewhat crude, emulation.

(Part 5) Next, their ATK. (Caster) Gilgamesh has (rounded to the nearest tenth) 8.4K ATK, which is under average for a 4-star servant, and Quetzalcoatl has (rounded to the nearest whole number) 12K attack, which is high, on average, for a 5-star servant.

(Part 4) We’ll be utilizing one of the informational sites I frequent in relation to F:GO, Gamepress.gg, we’ll be using their staff created servant profiles to list their stats, skills and Command Card (Command Cards are attacks) deck. First, their HP. (Caster) Gilgamesh has 12.05k HP, which is slightly above average for a 4-star servant, and Quetzalcoatl has 12.96k HP, which is relatively average for a 5-star servant. For simplicities sake, I’ll be rounding them to 12k HP and 13k HP respectively. This will apply later, when necessary, as well.

(Part 3) Now, with that digression out of the way, we can finally start setting the playing field. (Caster) Gilgamesh is a 4-star servant. The rank itself means nothing, it’s the stats that come along with the rank and the skills he possesses that seals his fate against Quetzalcoatl. For the best explanation, we shall be comparing and contrasting their chemistry under their max level stats and max level skills.

(Part 2) A servant without CA (Class Advantage) will deal Normal Damage and receive Normal Damage. A servant with CA will deal twice their Normal Damage, henceforth the term ‘Effective Damage’, and take half the Normal Damage from the enemy servant, which is called ‘Resist Damage’. A servant with CD (Class Disadvantage) will deal half as much Normal Damage, henceforth the term ‘Resist Damage’, and take twice as much damage. There are exceptions for a class or two, but not in this case.

(Part 1) Why Quetzalcoatl would, and I quote, “absolutely wreck his weak 4* ass.” To answer that we’re gonna have to talk about Class Dis/Advantages, stats, skills, and overall performance in a hypothetical fight between (Caster) Gilgamesh and Quetzalcoatl. First we will center this part of the hypothetical battle solely around the technical game mechanics. Before we get into it, let’s get one thing out of the way. You see, casters are weak to riders. In F:GO Class Dis/Advantages make huge differences, although there are some exceptions story-wise. But the majority rules; and in this case there is no exception, technical nor story-wise.
